newsitem.title: UK: Britain's Oxford unveils new plan for Saudi school.
newsitem.headline: Britain's Oxford unveils new plan for Saudi school.

text.p: Britain's Oxford University said on Friday it had found a new home for a controversial business school to be part-funded by Saudi entrepreneur Wafic Said.
"The creation of a world-class business school at Oxford has been an important objective for the university since 1990," said the university's vice-chancellor Peter North.
North praised Said's "almost unparalleled generosity" and expressed hope the university could get over "past controversies" to make his vision a reality.
Said's ambitious project -- and benefaction of 20 million pounds ($33 million) -- has fierce opponents at the ancient university.
Critics are wary of Said's influence over the business school's affairs and angry at the manner in which the university has handled the project.
Previous plans to build the school on a sports field were rejected by the so-called congregation: a parliament of university dons. Oxford had promised to preserve the fields as a green site.
The dons (college fellows) must now approve the new, alternative site close to the city railway station at a meeting slated for June 17.
The university said it and Said had agreed on the alternative site after "consideration of the relevant issues".
"An exhaustive search found it to be the only available site which was central, financeable and of a scale appropriate to the intended prestige of the new institution," it said in a statement.
The Said Business Foundation would oversee the construction and aid the development of the school but would have no say in academic issues or the day-to-day running of the school.
Oxford said four of the trustees would be appointed by Said, to include himself, a further four by the vice-chancellor and the remaining two by top business figures.
"These arrangements achieve the benefactor's objective of the majority of the trustees coming from the world of business," Oxford said.
Previous plans had given Said a say in six of the appointments, a proposal rejected by many university staff as too interfering. ($ = 0.610 British Pounds)
